channel.title: Speeding up EV charging | Graphene permeability discovery | Thin film solar cell with flexible substrate | Electrolyte design for batteries | Generating electricity from organic hydrides | Plus products
channel.description: In this issue: Unravelling graphene's proton permeability

description.p: Excessive heat in equipment reduces its service life and adversely impacts its performance. Proper selection of cooling elements can help avoid these negative effects.

item.title: SCHURTER Sets New Benchmark in Reducing CO2 Footprint with Latest Product — Green Line
item.description: As part of SCHURTER's sustainable strategy, the IEC 60320-1 appliance connectors contribute to less CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and lower material consumption.

item.title: Q&A: Mark Burr-Lonnon on the future of the electronics industry
item.description: Mark Burr-Lonnon from Mouser Electronics describes coming trends in the electronics industry, such as artificial intelligence, automation, and IoT.

item.title: Unravelling graphene's proton permeability
item.description: Researchers have demonstrated that perfect graphene crystals are permeable to protons, as the protons are expedited around nanoscale wrinkles in the crystal.

item.title: Suppressing lithium plating in batteries for fast-charging EVs
item.description: A new way to prevent lithium plating in electric vehicle (EV) batteries could lead to faster charging times, according to researchers from the UK.

item.title: Transparent thin-film solar cell developed with flexible substrate
item.description: Researchers have developed a transparent thin-film solar cell on a flexible substrate that displays various reflective colours without reducing solar cell efficiency.
